Award.AwardTitle: Convergence Accelerator Phase I (RAISE): Connecting Indiana's Learn-And-Work Ecosystem
Award.AbstractNarration:
The NSF Convergence Accelerator supports team-based, multidisciplinary efforts that address challenges of national importance and show potential for deliverables in the near future.

The broader impact/potential benefit of this Convergence Accelerator Phase I project is to enable American workers to successfully navigate their career by accessing and sharing information pertaining to credentials and jobs using connected data exchanges. Exchanging career goals, records, credentials, competencies, assessments, job descriptions, and pathways as machine-actionable data will be foundational to realizing this goal. Because the education and employment sectors have many different documentation policies, processes, roles, and governance, this project engages a wide range of experts. The leadership team represents multiple disciplines including education, government, business, computer science, philanthropy, policy, educational psychology, and ethics. Indiana is an ideal context for this research because multiple related initiatives are actively but independently being developed across the state. Phase I activities will build an extensive partner network to document how each initiative's data exchanges can connect in support of particular use cases. Identified data gaps limit the value of these initiatives and will be added to a roadmap for eliminating technical barriers. Similar to how connected data exchanges have rapidly improved the travel industry, we believe state-level governance of key data exchanges will accelerate innovative applications for workers and help other state leaders advance similar initiatives.

This Convergence Accelerator Phase I project focuses on a state-level governance gap concerning the connections among key data exchanges supporting students, education providers, workers, and employers. In Indiana, as in other states, these data exchanges are at varying points of development and adoption. Ensuring these data exchanges are sufficiently connected to support key use cases is dependent upon voluntary efforts and weakly instantiated into the business processes of specification organizations themselves. As industries increasingly become "information-based", competing business models have the potential to delay or even derail innovative applications and/or inadvertently centralize control of key data exchanges. Our research objective is to advance knowledge concerning how states could better address these problems via team-building activities. Specifically, data experts will be convened to define evaluation criteria for analyzing data exchange information. Indiana education providers and employers will also be engaged directly via two multi-disciplinary workshops to document important Indiana use cases and supportive data exchanges, such as searching for a certificate program based on a competency required in a job description. As a result, the project team will create a prioritized roadmap, a toolkit for state leaders, and a Phase II proposal for connecting Indiana?s learn and work ecosystem.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Providing educational opportunities so people can get good jobs is one of the most important responsibilities of a state. Aligning education and work sounds easy, but it's not. Data systems are siloed from one another and many barriers inhibit better connections, including ambiguous role responsibilities, schema differences, encoding differences, software capabilities, staff capacity, and data quality concerns. Multiple state agencies in Indiana are trying to solve these problems using the openly-licensed Credential Transparency Description language (CTDL) to make information about credentials transparent to the public, and by aligning competencies taught by educators with those sought by employers. 

The multi-disciplinary Phase 1 team researched Indiana's progress and experienced barriers in order to define a feasible solution to these challenges as articulated in our Midwest Compact for a Connected Learn-and-Work Ecosystem Phase 2 proposal. Specifically, the team conducted multiple activities with a broad set of state and national stakeholders representing students, workers, educational technology vendors, secondary administrators, post-secondary administrators, faculty, career counselors, state agencies, elected government officials, regional non-profits, philanthropic leaders, librarians, professional associations, ethicists, and employers. Insights gleaned from NSF convenings and IDEO presentations helped the team plan engage activities for this broad set of stakeholders. 

Three types of Phase 1 interviews suggested ways to improve the proposed Phase 2 work for maximum state, regional, and national impact. Eight taped interviews were conducted as part of the in-person, team-building meetings, covering a range of stakeholder perspectives, from state agency heads to senior vendor developers and economic development leaders. Twelve taped interviews were conducted with potential individual users and user groups. The interviews included a range of potential learners, from high school and current college students to transfer students and adults needing re-skilling, such as veterans. Other interviews were conducted with people who work with learners of all backgrounds, such as high school and community college advisors. Five interviews were also conducted with technology officers for Indiana credentialing organizations concerning their data management practices. Collectively, these interviews provided key insights into data requirements for a variety of users and confirmed the need for better technical product support for data management and interoperability.

Three Phase 1 workshops were held in order to promote a shared vision of a connected learn and work ecosystem and to identify relevant use cases. A total of 220 participants attended these workshops, with 192 attendees or 87 percent from Indiana and 28 attendees or 13 percent from out-of-state. 

A survey of Midwestern Higher Education Compact's commissioners (mostly state legislatures, agency leaders, and governor appointees) identified current state priorities, perceptions of stakeholder engagement, and preferences amongst various facilitation activities. Results confirmed the importance of credential attainment for state economic outcomes and highly varying approaches to stakeholder engagement. Small in-person or web-based convenings were consistently identified as effective activities. Ninety-five percent of respondents endorsed a partnership approach to Phase 2.

A large volume of additional data was also published to the Registry during Phase I, including tuition and fees for all 3,000+ certificate and degree programs, credit hours required for all 3,000+ certificate and degree programs, all programs available for delivery via distance education, competencies for all associate degrees at Ivy Tech Community College, links to selected licenses and licensing boards, and 30+ high schools at which postsecondary credentials are available.

Google Pathways developed and launched in January 2020 an Indiana Pathways pilot app, which draws on CTDL data from the Credential Registry and links to in-demand occupations in Indiana. A regional prototype of EMSI's CareerCoach was developed to consume Credential Engine data. A Bendable app is consuming data from the Credential Registry for the South Bend area. Indiana Commission for Higher Education, in collaboration with multiple state agencies, is defining career exploration tool requirements to consume Credential Registry data on education and training providers. The commission is also enhancing its Indiana e-Transcript Program by contracting with Parchment on its digital diploma/credential product to provide a link to credential information contained in the Credential Registry.

Several official public statements were also made during Phase 1 embracing credential transparency and the work of Credential Engine, including Indiana's new, quadrennial strategic plan, Reaching Higher in a State of Change and Strategic Workforce Plan, formulated by the Governor's Workforce Cabinet, and the American Workforce Policy Advisory Board's white paper on Interoperable Learning Records.

The primary outcome of these Phase 1 activities is our Phase 2 proposal to strengthen America's learn-and-work ecosystem by assembling a critical mass of linked open data using mature, open technologies including the CTDL schema and Credential Registry. We propose using a state agency strategy, partnering with the Midwestern Higher Education Compact and several national organizations, to harness their collective power to develop and sustain AI-powered applications supporting learners of all ages, employers, educators, and other stakeholders. For more information, see https://bit.ly/ConnectedEcosystem
